ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course content is very interesting. I learned about the idea of storytelling and saw how it applied in films.

This course did an amazing job of developing my storytelling skills and giving me insight into the structure of most, if not every story I have heard. I learned to be able to analyze stories through an Aristotelian lens in a fun way.

Because I enjoy creative writing, I had been looking forward to taking this course, and it did not disappoint. I was able to gain significant insight about the nature of classical storytelling across generations and varying cultures. I feel that I have left this course with a significantly deeper understanding about the structures and components of stories, which I hope to continue to incorporate for as long as I continue to write.
I learned how to analyze the structure of stories, and how to better appreciate the films and tales I read and hear. Additionally it helped me to appreciate the necessity of storytelling to humanity.
I learned a lot about the structure of screenplays and the components necessary to write a good story according to Aristotle which I can now see applicable across so many American films.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course's strength was Professor Price. He is so down-to-earth and approachable, and he makes learning from Poetics and doing assignments enjoyable. There were no weaknesses.
Only strengths, great professor and engaging class

This course's main strength is the structure of the classes that allows for significant discussion to take place. I personally thought having consistent feedback about my ideas from the professor and other students was very helpful in developing my own thoughts. I also believe that the course helps facilitate learning through experience. Because students must observe the nature of stories themselves, through their own commitment to watching movies and evaluating stories, the content material from the professor is very easy to apply.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, the teacher is wonderful and engaging

YES YES YES. This was my favorite class this semester, and it was so fun and insightful. Not only was the class a break from other classes, but I feel like I learned a lot about storytelling and screenwriting.

I would highly recommend this course to any student. It helped me gain a more profound appreciation for stories, and helped me explore interesting Western screenwriting from before the 2000s, which I admittedly had limited exposure to. This course could be taken by any student in any major and be a positive experience for that student, through and through.
Absolutely. Its an incredibly interesting introduction to the world of storytelling and film taught by an erudite and understanding professor. Youd be crazy to not want to take it.

As a STEM major who has an interest in film making/story telling, I am so glad that I took this class. It was definitely an interesting and fun gut where I got to explore something outside of my major that I was still interested in to fufill a humanities requirement. I know this course is popular to take as a FYS, so I would only take it if you have an interest in the material and not just for the gutiness because that takes away from other students who really want to take this course.
